title: How to Rent Furniture for Staging

steps.headline: Look up furniture rental companies in your area.
steps.description: Run a search for “furniture rentals” plus the name of your town, city, or province. Furniture rental businesses are more common than you might expect, as they cater to businesses, realtors, individual homeowners, and even members of the entertainment industry. This means you’re likely to find one near you. Many furniture rental companies are chains, with multiple stores located throughout a particular region. Some furniture stores allow customers to lease pieces temporarily. Try asking around at conventional retailers if your search doesn’t turn up any dedicated rental centers.

steps.headline: Visit a company’s website for more information.
steps.description: Pick a rental company from your search results to take a closer look at what they have to offer. Viewing a company’s website will give you a better idea of the exact services they provide, as well as their signature decorating style and general price range. Compare several different rental companies (assuming you have more than a couple to choose from) to find one that best suits your sensibilities and budget. It can also be helpful to read some reviews of the companies your search pulls up to find out what kind of experiences other customers have had with them.

steps.headline: Call the company to speak with a representative directly.
steps.description: If you like what you see on a particular company’s website, call them up and discuss the details of the rental process. A quick chat will give you a chance to learn about the company’s products and policies and ask whatever questions you might have. Some good questions to ask include "Where do you source your furniture? ", "Is it possible to pick out pieces individually?" and "How long does a standard rental agreement last?" You can usually find a company’s contact information in the upper or lower part of their website. If you don’t see it there, look for a “Contact Us” tab on their homepage. You’ll be able to get faster and more detailed answers with a phone conversation than you could by corresponding via email.

parts.name: Choosing the Right Furnishings for Your Living Space

steps.headline: Determine how much furniture you need.
steps.description: If you're staging your whole house for walkthroughs, you'll want to have enough pieces on display to tie each room together. This will call for large, coordinated items like beds, armoires, tables, and seating areas. If you're only planning on listing 1 or 2 rooms, you can probably get away with renting a single set of furnishings in your preferred theme. There's no need to fill out every room from wall to wall—the idea is simply to give interested parties a sense of what a particular room would look like once it's furnished. When staging an office, focus on attention-grabbing pieces that will expect to see, such as desks, filing cabinets, client seating, and display cases for awards and distinctions.

steps.headline: Pick out furniture by style.
steps.description: The pieces leased by furniture rental companies are typically grouped together as packages based on popular decorating themes such as modern, rustic, urban, and townhouse. Browsing by style is probably the easiest way to find furniture that complements your living space without having to select each item individually. When you shop by style, you’ll receive a complete set of furnishings that have been curated based on a common look. Furniture packages are often categorized by room, which makes it possible to mix-and-match different styles between rooms. For example, you might fill your living room with contemporary minimalist pieces and select a rustic French chateau motif for the master bedroom.

steps.headline: Search pieces by price point.
steps.description: If you’re working on a budget, see if you can filter your search results by price. You’ll then be shown only the items that are priced at or below the maximum amount you’re willing to pay. This will help keep the final cost of your staging project as low as possible. Complete furniture packages typically range in price from $150-400 per month, while individual pieces may be listed for as low as $15-30. Keep in mind that staging your home is intended to raise its perceived value. By sticking to a predetermined price point, you can avoid overspending and ultimately walk away with more to show for your efforts.

steps.headline: Compare items from the company’s inventory individually.
steps.description: Online catalogs, showrooms, or stores make it easy to shop for furniture one piece at a time. There, you’ll find items separated by type, such as beds, sofas, tables, chairs, and lighting fixtures. Some companies even stock functional appliances and other accessories like wall art and miscellaneous decorations. Be sure to write down the name or item number of each piece along with its price to keep track of how much you can expect to spend. Picking out furniture individually can be useful when you’re sprucing up a room that doesn’t fall into one of the usual categories, or you want to put your own personal touch on your living space. In some cases, it may be possible to add individual items to a pre-curated package for an additional charge.

steps.headline: Shop for accessories to provide the finishing touches.
steps.description: Before you check out, take a look at some of the decorative items the company has available, like rugs, mirrors, throw pillows, potted plants, and eye-catching knickknacks. These items are perfect for giving homes a lived-in quality, especially in cozy, intimate quarters like bedrooms and bathrooms. Consider spending a little extra on a few wall hangings, sculptures, and other pieces of artwork. The right selections can make any home feel more cultured. Depending on how extensive a company's inventory is, you might even be able to find small accessories like woven baskets, candles, and flower arrangements for as little as a few dollars apiece.

steps.headline: Seek advice from a qualified staging consultant.
steps.description: If you don’t know the first thing about the finer points of interior decorating, request the assistance of a staging specialist. They’ll be able to make recommendations based on your home’s unique features and walk you through the process of getting it show-ready from beginning to end. Many furniture rental companies employ their own designers to help customers stage their homes more effectively. Their services can usually be secured with an additional consulting fee. Not all companies have consultants on staff. If the one you’re leasing from doesn’t, it may be necessary to hire an outside staging expert. Search for "home staging consultant" along with the name of your city or province to find one who operates near you.

steps.headline: Sign a lease agreement.
steps.description: After you’ve made up your mind which package or pieces you want, a rental agent will go over all the necessary paperwork with you, including a formal rental contract. This contract simply states that you’re paying to lease the items mentioned for an agreed-upon time. Leases are typically offered for 6, 12, 18, or 24 month periods. As a general rule, the longer your lease, the better deal you’ll get. Review the rental agreement closely before you put your name on it. You’ll want to know if there are any additional costs or provisions hidden within the document’s wording.

steps.headline: Pay your first month’s rent.
steps.description: This can ordinarily be done online, though you also have the option of using a credit card or cash if you’ve paid a trip to the rental office in person. Once you make your first payment, you’ll be in legal possession of the items until you miss a payment or your lease comes to an end. You may have to set up an online account through the rental company’s website in order to manage your monthly payments. See about setting up automatic recurring payments, if possible. That way, you can make sure you don’t accidentally miss a payment.

steps.headline: Schedule a time for delivery.
steps.description: Let the rental agent know what date and time works best for you. They’ll pass the word along to the delivery team, who will drop off your furniture and accessories when it’s convenient. Most furniture rental companies guarantee swift delivery within 2 business days. Make sure you give yourself and your stager plenty of time before you begin showing your home. For smaller living spaces, this might only take a few hours, while for larger properties you may need 2-3 full days to get everything in place.

steps.headline: Provide input during set up.
steps.description: Don’t be afraid to speak up when inspiration strikes or you disagree with one of your stager’s decisions. Just because you’re borrowing your furniture from an outside source doesn’t mean they’re calling the shots. Ultimately, you have the final say when it comes to how your home is presented. Chances are, your stager will be more than happy to collaborate with you to enhance the visual appeal of your living space. Consider handling the decorating duties yourself if you have a particular way you want things done.

steps.headline: Schedule a time to return your rented furniture.
steps.description: As your rental agreement nears its expiration date, a rental agent will contact you to work out a specific time and date for pickup. The moving team will then be dispatched once again to load everything up and take it back to the company warehouse for inspection and storage. Most furniture rental companies ask lessees to schedule a pickup at least 2 weeks in advance. With some companies, you might also be able to return rented items as soon as you're done staging your home, usually after it's sold or you've taken photos. You may be subjected to additional expenses for furniture and accessories that are returned damaged.
